Michael Stack wrote:
> Why the multiple spaces between fields?  Makes logs ~30% bigger than 
> then need to be.

The fields up to the URI are justified with extra spaces for easier
human readability: all lengths, statuses, and URIs line up for
at-a-glance comparisons. Fields after the URI are ragged, delimited
by a single space.

The size boost should be much less than 30% per line, and if
log size ever became critical we coulg GZIP them on the fly,
making the marginal cost of runs of spaces negligible...

> You make the result codes negative to distingush from the HTTP status 
> code returned?  Otherwise I'd suggest reusing them (E.g: 408 Request 
> Timeout  instead of  "-4 E_SoTime Socket Timeout").  Otherwise,  +1.

Negative has been the existing convention; that should become an
external detail once symbolic statuses in logs are implemented.

As they currently appear in the same log field, reuse of similar
codes would make it ambiguous as to whether the error came over
the net or was generated by a local condition.

> All sounds good.
> 
> Do we have any reporting tools to go against our logs?

Not yet, but we could start collecting Igor's most useful
postprocessing/reporting scripts into CVS somewhere.

- Gordon
